facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 1475 of 1970 is an appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated 29th May 1970 of the High Court of Delhi in Second Appeal No. 25-D of 1966.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 1475 of 1970. Appeal by Special Leave from the Judgment and Order. dated the 29th May, 1970 of the High Court of Delhi in Second Appeal No. 25-D of 1966.

facts.text: Respondent landlord let out the premises in suit to the appellant on or about September 10, 1959 on a rent of Rs. 125/- per month. The premises consisted of a shop.

anchor.surface_text: On or about September 10, 1959 the respondent landlord let out the premises in suit to the appellant on a rent of Rs. 125/- per month. The premises companysisted of a shop.

facts.text: On 1-9-1962 the respondent applied under section 14 of the Delhi Rent Control Act to the Rent Controller, Delhi for evicting the appellant on the ground of sub-letting the entire premises to Sohan Singh.

anchor.surface_text: On 1-9- 1962 the respondent applied under section 14 of the above Act to the Rent Controller, Delhi for evicting the appellant on the ground that she had sub-let the entire premises to one Sohan Singh who, according to the respondent, was running a business under the name of Royal Dispensing Chemists and Druggists in the shop.

facts.text: Respondent alleged that Sohan Singh was running a business under the name of Royal Dispensing Chemists and Druggists in the shop and appellant was charging fabulous rent from sub-tenant Sohan Singh.

anchor.surface_text: who, according to the respondent, was running a business under the name of Royal Dispensing Chemists and Druggists in the shop. It was further alleged that the appellant was charging a fabulous amount as rent from her sub-tenant Sohan Singh.

facts.text: Appellant admitted tenancy but denied sub-letting and alleged that Sohan Singh was her husband and from the time of the lease the business of a Chemist was being run there by her husband and she occasionally helped.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant in her written statement admitted the tenancy but denied sub- letting. She alleged that Sohan Singh was her husband and from the time of the lease the business of a Chemist was being run there in the premises by her husband and she also occasionally helped him in the running of the business.

facts.text: Rent Controller held that appellant was the legally wedded wife of Sohan Singh or they were living together as husband and wife, therefore no sub-letting.

anchor.surface_text: The Rent Controller was of the view that the appellant was the legally Wedded wife of Sohan Singh. In any event he held, Sohan Singh and the appellant were living together as husband and wife and, therefore, there was numberquestion of any sub--letting by the appellant of the premises.

facts.text: Rent Control Tribunal confirmed the Rent Controller's finding of no sub-letting.

anchor.surface_text: That finding was companyfirmed in appeal by the Rent Control Tribunal, Delhi.

facts.text: Respondent filed second appeal to High Court under section 39 of the Delhi Rent Control Act.

anchor.surface_text: Aggrieved by the decision, the respondent went in second appeal to the High Court under section 39 1  of the Act.

facts.text: High Court single Judge held there was sub-letting in favour of Sohan Singh and ordered eviction of appellant.

anchor.surface_text: The learned single Judge agreed that the appeal involved substantial questions of law as submitted, and came to the companyclusion that there was sub-setting in favour of Sohan Singh. Accordingly, he gave an order for evicting the appellant.

facts.text: Appellant and Sohan Singh were living together as husband and wife.

anchor.surface_text: The simple question which had to be determined in the case was whether having regard to the fact that the appellant and Sohan Singh were living as husband and wife, it was open to draw, in the absence of evidence to the companytrary, the factual inference that the wife had sub-let the premises to her husband.

facts.text: From the time of the lease, chemist business was run in the premises by Sohan Singh with occasional help from appellant.

anchor.surface_text: She alleged that Sohan Singh was her husband and from the time of the lease the business of a Chemist was being run there in the premises by her husband and she also occasionally helped him in the running of the business.

facts.text: Respondent produced no evidence to show sub-letting despite appellant's denial.

anchor.surface_text: In the present case the respondent produced numberevidence to show such sub-letting in spite of the appellants denial in the written statement of any sub-letting.

facts.text: Sohan Singh's first wife testified she had no knowledge of marriage but knew they lived together for about six years before 1963.

anchor.surface_text: He called Sohan Singhs first wife as his first witness in this case but all that the lady was able to say was that she had numberknowledge if the appellant was married to Sohan Singh but she knew that he lived with the appellant since about six years before her deposition, recorded in 1963.

facts.text: Respondent admitted he never enquired if appellant and Sohan Singh are husband and wife and could not deny they were living together.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent himself in his testimony admitted that he had never himself made any enquiry as to whether Sohan Singh and the appellant are husband and wife or number. Nor companyld he deny that they were living together.

facts.text: Appellant passed a rent note in respondent's favour where respondent wrote that appellant was wife of Sohan Singh.

anchor.surface_text: The appel- lant had passed a rent numbere in the respondents favour and it was the case of the appellant that in that rent numbere the respondent had in his own handwriting written that the appellant was the wife of Sohan Singh.

facts.text: Typed copy of rent note accepted by respondent as true copy, disclosing appellant accepted as wife of Sohan Singh.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant summoned him to produce his rent numbere but the respondent did number produce it. So in his cross examination he was shown a typed companyy of it and this he accepted as a true companyy. The true companyy disclosed that the appellant was accepted as the wife of Sohan Singh.

facts.text: Chemist's shop was opened in premises in 1959 run principally by Sohan Singh but occasionally by appellant.

anchor.surface_text: the appel- lant and Sohan Singh were living as husband and wife and from the day the rent numbere was passed by the appellant in 1959 a Chemists shop was opened in the premises which was run principally by Sohan Singh but occasionally by the appellant also.

facts.text: Supreme Court holds no sub-letting and restores Rent Control Authorities' orders.

anchor.surface_text: The appeal is, therefore, allowed, the order passed by the High Court is set aside and that of the Rent Control Authorities is restored with companyts throughout.

facts.text: Onus to prove sub-letting is on landlord.

anchor.surface_text: When eviction is sought on that ground it is number settled law that the onus to prove sub-letting is on the landlord.

facts.text: Appellant and Sohan Singh gave evidence they were living as husband and wife and looking after the business.

anchor.surface_text: Besides, when the appellant and Sohan Singh gave evidence of the ,fact that they were living as husband and wife and looking after the  1  1968 2 S.C.R. 548. business in the shop there was hardly any cross examination on the point.

facts.text: Rent Controller specifically pointed out that whether legally married or not, living as husband and wife sufficient.

anchor.surface_text: It was sufficient for the Rent Court to proceed on the finding that the appellant and Sohan Singh were living as husband and wife, whether they were legally married or number. This was specifically pointed out by the Additional Rent Controller in his judgment.

facts.text: Basic facts: appellant took lease in 1959, chemist business from time of letting by Sohan Singh with appellant's help.

anchor.surface_text: The basic facts in the present case were  1  the appellant and Sohan Singh were living as husband and wife to the knowledge of the respondent  2  the appellant took the lease of the shop premises from the respondent in 1959  3  from the time of the letting a Chemists business was carried in the shop by Sohan Singh with the occasional help of the appellant.

anchor.surface_text: Sub-section  4  of section 14 is as follows For the purposes of clause  b  of the proviso to sub-section  1 ,any premises which have been let for being used for the purposes of business or profession shall be deemed to have been sub-let by the tenant, if the Controller is satisfied that the tenant without obtaining the companysent in writing of the landlord has, after the 16th day of August, 1958, allowed any person or occupy the whole or any part of the premises ostensibly on the ground that such person is a partner of the tenant in the business or profession but really for the purpose of sub-letting such premises to that person.

concepts.interpretation: Deeming provision for sub-letting in business premises if person allowed ostensibly as partner but really for sub-letting; no application where not owner letting in partner.

interpretation_anchor.surface_text: companypletely parted with possession without the written companysent of the respondent. It was also alleged that the appellant was charging fabulous

concepts.unlisted_description: Deems sub-letting in business cases involving sham partnerships post 16.8.1958.

anchor.surface_text: The simple question which had to be determined in the case was whether having regard to the fact that the appellant and Sohan Singh were living as husband and wife, it was open to draw, in the absence of evidence to the companytrary, the factual inference that the wife had sub-let the premises to her husband. Sub-letting like letting, is a particular type of demise of immovable property and is distinct from permissive user like that of a licensee.

concepts.interpretation: Particular type of demise distinct from permissive user or licensee; no sub-letting where husband-wife living together and business run from inception without evidence of parting possession for consideration.

anchor.surface_text: clause b of the proviso to sub-section 1 of section 14 of the Act read with sub-section 4 of that section. The provisions are as follows 14 1 Provided that the Controller may, on an application made to him in the prescribed manner, make an order for the recovery of possession of the premises on one or more of the following grounds only, namely a b that the tenant has, on or after the 9th day of June, 1952 sub-let, assigned or otherwise parted with the possession of the whole or any part of the premises without obtaining the consent in writing of the landlord Sub-section 4 of section 14 is as follows For the purposes of clause b of the proviso to sub-section 1 ,any premises which have been let for being used for the purposes of business or profession shall be deemed to have been sub-let by the tenant, if the Controller is satisfied that the tenant without obtaining the consent in writing of the landlord has, after the 16th day of August, 1958, allowed any person to occupy the whole or any part of the premises ostensibly on the ground that such person is a partner of the tenant in the business or profession but really for the purpose of sub-letting such premises to that person.

anchor.surface_text: The evidence was clear namely, that to the knowledge of the respondent, the appellant and Sohan Singh were living as husband and wife and from the day the rent note was passed by the appellant in 1959 a Chemists shop was opened in the premises which was run principally by Sohan Singh but occasionally by the appellant also. The question is whether that evidence gives rise to the factual inference that the appellant had sublet the premises to Sohan Singh.

issues.text: one relating to the status of the appellant as the alleged wife of Sohan Singh and the second whether on the facts found, sub-letting was established

anchor.surface_text: This was a concurrent finding of fact and it seems to us that the learned counsel for the appellant is right in contending that the High Court in second appeal should not have interfered with that finding especially when section 39 2 of the Act provides that no appeal shall lie to the High Court unless the appeal involved some substantial question of law. The learned single Judge thought that two substantial questions of law were involved-one relating to the status of the appellant as the alleged wife of Sohan Singh and the second whether on the facts found, sub-letting was established.

issues.text: whether it is a mixed question of law and fact

anchor.surface_text: Both these questions involved, according to the learned Judge, substantial questions of mixed fact and law. As to the first question whether the appellant was legally married, that was a question on which no finding was necessary in an eviction suit. ... As regards the second question, one does not see how it is a mixed question of law and fact.

It was further alleged that the appellant was charging a fabulous amount as rent from her sub-tenant Sohan Singh.

It was contended before the court by the respondent that two substantial questions of law and fact were involved in the appeal-one relating to the status of the appellant as wife and the other whether on the facts found the ground of sub-letting had been established.

arguments.claim: Appeal involves substantial questions of law; there was sub-letting in favour of Sohan Singh warranting eviction

arguments.court_reasoning: Erred in treating as matrimonial proceeding; presumed sub-letting without evidence; s14(4) inapplicable; interfered with concurrent fact findings without substantial Q of law

arguments.claim: High Court erred by interfering with pure concurrent finding of fact on sub-letting; no substantial question of law under section 39(2)

anchor.surface_text: So this appeal by special leave. It is contended on behalf of the appellant that the learned single Judge has interfered with a pure finding of fact. Under section 39 2  of the Act the High Court could interfere in second appeal only if there was a substantial question of law. In the present case, he submitted, there was no question of law, much less substantial question of law and, therefore, the High Court was in error in interfering with the concurrent finding of the Rent Control authorities

court_response_anchor.surface_text: of law. In the present case, he submitted, there was numberquestion of law, much less substantial question of law and, therefore, the High Court was i

arguments.court_reasoning: Great force in contention; no substantial Q of law involved

arguments.claim: Even assuming appellant is wife of Sohan Singh, she must be presumed to have sub-let premises to him for business

anchor.surface_text: And that is what the learned single Judge has done in the present case. He was of the view that even if it is assumed that the appellant was the wife of Sohan Singh, she, who was entitled to possession of the shop premises as a tenant, must be presumed to have sub-let the same to Sohan Singh to carry on his business,

court_response_anchor.surface_text: as dealt with the case as if this is a matrimonial proceeding-in which the status of the appellant as the wife of Sohan M8--602 SUP CI/74 Singh was un

arguments.court_reasoning: Rash inference without other evidence; sub-letting distinct from permissive user in H-W relationship

arguments.claim: Sub-section 4 of section 14 deems sub-letting where tenant allows partner ostensibly but for sub-letting; applies here

anchor.surface_text: In support of this conclusion he relied on clause b of the proviso to sub-section 1 of section 14 of the Act read with sub-section 4 of that section. The provisions are as follows 14 1 Provided that the Controller may, on an application made to him in the prescribed manner, make an order for the recovery of possession of the premises on one or more of the following grounds only, namely a b that the tenant has, on or after the 9th day of June, 1952 sub-let, assigned or otherwise parted with the possession of the whole or any part of the premises without obtaining the consent in writing of the landlord Sub-section 4 of section 14 is as follows For the purposes of clause b of the proviso to sub-section 1 ,any premises which have been let for being used for the purposes of business or profession shall be deemed to have been sub-let by the tenant, if the Controller is satisfied that the tenant without obtaining the consent in writing of the landlord has, after the 16th day of August, 1958, allowed any person to occupy the whole or any part of the premises ostensibly on the ground that such person is a partner of the tenant in the business or profession but really for the purpose of sub-letting such premises to that person.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: companypletely parted with possession without the written companysent of the respondent. It was also alleged that the appellant was charging fabulous

arguments.court_reasoning: No application as not case of owner letting in partner ostensibly; appellant not owner of business letting in partner

arguments.claim: Onus to prove sub-letting is on landlord; prima facie case shifts to tenant; here landlord failed to produce evidence despite denial

anchor.surface_text: When eviction is sought on that ground it is well settled law that the onus to prove sub-letting is on the landlord. If the landlord prima-facie shows that the occupant who was in exclusive possession of the premises let out for valuable consideration, it would then be for the tenant to rebut the evidence. In the present case the respondent produced no evidence to show such sub-letting in spite of the appellants denial in the written statement of any sub-letting.

arguments.claim: Evidence shows appellant and Sohan Singh living as husband-wife to respondent's knowledge; business from 1959 inception; no sub-letting inference

anchor.surface_text: The evidence was clear namely, that to the knowledge of the respondent, the appellant and Sohan Singh were living as husband and wife and from the day the rent note was passed by the appellant in 1959 a Chemists shop was opened in the premises which was run principally by Sohan Singh but occasionally by the appellant also. The question is whether that evidence gives rise to the factual inference that the appellant had sublet the premises to Sohan Singh.

arguments.claim: High Court erred in interfering with concurrent finding of fact; section 39(2) requires substantial question of law which absent here

anchor.surface_text: This was a concurrent finding of fact and it seems to us that the learned counsel for the appellant is right in contending that the High Court in second appeal should not have interfered with that finding especially when section 39 2 of the Act provides that no appeal shall lie to the High Court unless the appeal involved some substantial question of law.

arguments.claim: Legal marital status irrelevant; living as husband-wife sufficient for no sub-letting finding

anchor.surface_text: It was sufficient for the Rent Court to proceed on the finding that the appellant and Sohan Singh were living as husband and wife, whether they were legally married or not. This was specifically pointed out by the Additional Rent Controller in his judgment.

arguments.claim: Whether sub-letting established is pure question of fact, not mixed law-fact; no legal principle application needed

anchor.surface_text: As regards the second question, one does not see how it is a mixed question of law and fact. In the determination of a question of fact no application of any principle of law is required in finding either the basic facts or arriving at the ultimate conclusion in a mixed question of law and fact the ultimate conclusion has to be drawn by applying principles of law to basic findings.

arguments.claim: Sub-letting is demise distinct from permissive user like licensee in husband-wife living together

anchor.surface_text: The simple question which had to be determined in the case was whether having regard to the fact that the appellant and Sohan Singh were living as husband and wife, it was open to draw, in the absence of evidence to the contrary, the factual inference that the wife had sub-let the premises to her husband. Sub-letting like letting, is a particular type of demise of immovable property and is distinct from permissive user like that of a licensee.

holdings.text: No substantial question of law was involved in the second appeal permitting High Court interference under section 39(2) of the Delhi Rent Control Act.

anchor.surface_text: This was a concurrent finding of fact and it seems to us that the learned counsel for the appellant is right in contending that the High Court in second appeal should not have interfered with that finding especially when section 39 2 of the Act provides that no appeal shall lie to the High Court unless the appeal involved some substantial question of law.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Concurrent finding of no sub-letting is pure fact; no application of legal principle required; status as wife irrelevant as living together sufficient.

holdings.text: The ground of sub-letting under section 14(1) proviso (b) was not established on the facts.

anchor.surface_text: The simple question which had to be determined in the case was whether having regard to the fact that the appellant and Sohan Singh were living as husband and wife, it was open to draw, in the absence of evidence to the contrary, the factual inference that the wife had sub-let the premises to her husband. Sub-letting like letting, is a particular type of demise of immovable property and is distinct from permissive user like that of a licensee.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Husband-wife living together and business from inception; no evidence of parting possession for consideration; onus on landlord not discharged.

holdings.text: Section 14(4) of the Delhi Rent Control Act has no application to the facts as there was no letting in of a person ostensibly as partner but really for sub-letting.

anchor.surface_text: Under sub-section 4 referred to above the premises could be deemed to have been sub-let by the tenant only when the Controller is satisfied that some person is let into possession ostensibly as a partner in business but really for the purposes of sub-letting. These provisions evidently have no application to the facts of the present case.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Deeming provision applies only to sham partnerships post-1958; not a case of tenant owning business letting in partner.

holdings.text: Landlord failed to discharge onus of proving sub-letting despite tenant's denial.

anchor.surface_text: When eviction is sought on that ground it is well settled law that the onus to prove sub-letting is on the landlord. If the landlord prima-facie shows that the occupant who was in exclusive possession of the premises let out for valuable consideration, it would then be for the tenant to rebut the evidence. In the present case the respondent produced no evidence to show such sub-letting in spite of the appellants denial in the written statement of any sub-letting.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Settled law places onus on landlord; no prima facie evidence produced despite denial and evidence of husband-wife relation.

holdings.text: Legal marital status irrelevant in eviction suit; living as husband and wife sufficient to negate sub-letting inference.

anchor.surface_text: It was sufficient for the Rent Court to proceed on the finding that the appellant and Sohan Singh were living as husband and wife, whether they were legally married or not. This was specifically pointed out by the Additional Rent Controller in his judgment.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Eviction not matrimonial proceeding; focus on possession transfer, not formal marriage.

holdings.text: Determination of sub-letting on these facts is a pure question of fact, not a mixed question of law and fact.

anchor.surface_text: As regards the second question, one does not see how it is a mixed question of law and fact. In the determination of a question of fact no application of any principle of law is required in finding either the basic facts or arriving at the ultimate conclusion in a mixed question of law and fact the ultimate conclusion has to be drawn by applying principles of law to basic findings.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No legal principle applied to basic facts of living together and business from start; commonsense factual inference.

holdings.text: Sub-letting is a demise distinct from permissive user by licensee, such as husband using premises with wife tenant.

anchor.surface_text: Sub-letting like letting, is a particular type of demise of immovable property and is distinct from permissive user like that of a licensee. If two persons live together in a house as husband and wife and one of them who owns the house allows the other to carry on business in a part of it

holdings.reasoning_summary: Applied to facts: no evidence of demise; akin to family permissive use from inception.

holdings.text: Appeal allowed; High Court order set aside; Rent Control Authorities' orders restored.

anchor.surface_text: The appeal is, therefore, allowed, the order passed by the High Court is set aside and that of the Rent Control Authorities is restored with costs throughout.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Cumulative effect of above holdings on jurisdiction, facts, and law application.

anchor.surface_text: This was a concurrent finding of fact and it seems to us that the learned counsel for the appellant is right in contending that the High Court in second appeal should not have interfered with that finding especially when section 39 2 of the Act provides that no appeal shall lie to the High Court unless the appeal involved some substantial question of law.

anchor.surface_text: The simple question which had to be determined in the case was whether having regard to the fact that the appellant and Sohan Singh were living as husband and wife, it was open to draw, in the absence of evidence to the contrary, the factual inference that the wife had sub-let the premises to her husband. Sub-letting like letting, is a particular type of demise of immovable property and is distinct from permissive user like that of a licensee.

edges.explanation: Holding h3 that Section 14(4) does not deem sub-letting supports holding h2 that the sub-letting ground under Section 14(1) Proviso (b) was not established.
Holding h3 rules that Section 14(4) has no application as there was no ostensible partnership for sub-letting, directly addressing issue i5.

anchor.surface_text: Under sub-section 4 referred to above the premises could be deemed to have been sub-let by the tenant only when the Controller is satisfied that some person is let into possession ostensibly as a partner in business but really for the purposes of sub-letting. These provisions evidently have no application to the facts of the present case.
The appeal is, therefore, allowed, the order passed by the High Court is set aside and that of the Rent Control Authorities is restored with costs throughout.

edges.explanation: Holding h4 on onus failure addresses i2 on establishment of sub-letting

anchor.surface_text: When eviction is sought on that ground it is well settled law that the onus to prove sub-letting is on the landlord. If the landlord prima-facie shows that the occupant who was in exclusive possession of the premises let out for valuable consideration, it would then be for the tenant to rebut the evidence. In the present case the respondent produced no evidence to show such sub-letting in spite of the appellants denial in the written statement of any sub-letting.
The appeal is, therefore, allowed, the order passed by the High Court is set aside and that of the Rent Control Authorities is restored with costs throughout.
